title: Will Syrian government forces retake the city of Aleppo before 1 July 2016?

With just hours to go, surely not. http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/hezbollah-syrian-govt-clash-over-aleppo-impossible-take-report-1337512772 "Hezbollah is reportedly refusing to back Syrian government forces in a proposed attack on Aleppo, arguing that the city – a bastion of the Syrian uprising – is "impossible" to take, according to a report by an Italian news agency citing sources within the Lebanese Shia movement. Hezbollah has been a key ally of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad during the country's five-year war but AdnKronos International (AKI) - which is headquartered in Italy but covers Arabic-language news - said on Wednesday the group had strategic differences with the government over its plans to recapture rebel-held areas of Syria's largest city with the aid of Russian air support.
Hezbollah sources close to the group's military operations in Syria told AKI: "We realised that it is impossible to take over the city, and thus it is dangerous to increase expansion without securing the areas neighbouring the expansion. This is in addition to the party suffering losses in its forces and in Iran-aligned forces.
“The party stressed to the Syrian forces that a battle such as this needs 100,000 fighters at least on the ground to succeed."

Very likely that Syrian government forces *will* retake Aleppo soon, perhaps in the next month. The current offensive seems to been redirected towards cutting off the rebels' supply lines, rather than taking the remaining rebel positions in the city itself. It seems now that the city will only fall to government forces if the Rebels decide to pull out. Given that they are facing being surrounded, it could make sense for them to do this (hence a prediction above 0%); however, in similar situations elsewhere (Damascus for instance) rebel forces have preferred to fight it out, or to rely on negotiated settlements rather than make a tactical withdrawal. The chances of Syrian troops retaking Aleppo by tomorrow seem very slim indeed, therefore.

This is a rapidly unfolding situation. In the past 24 hours, Syrian government troops have made major gains to the north of the city. Some reports state that Syrian army units have penetrated, and are holding parts of the city centre. There are also reports suggesting that government troops wish to take the city completely by the end of Ramadan in order to maximise the propaganda value of their victory. Certainly, continuing air strikes and heavy shelling suggest that a significant offensive is under way.  Whether Aleppo will actually fall in the next 24-48 hours (before 1 July) is unclear, however. The rebels' declining military position in northern Syria is such that to lose Aleppo would seriously undermine them, which may make the defence of the city more determined. On the other hand, the rebels probably have more to gain by cutting their losses and pulling out in order to reinforce Idlib, and the more easily-defensible positions in the mountains to the west.  It seems likely that Aleppo will fall soon, and there is good reason to think that Syrian government forces are now in a strong position to push for a quick resolution; however, given the rate of progress so far, it is far from certain that it will fall before 1 July. Regaining control of the city outright would be a major win for the Assad government. It remains relatively secure in the capital Damascus, while the city of Homs -- along with Aleppo one of the cradles of the original 2011 uprising -- was regained from rebel forces in May 2014. Should they be able to take Aleppo, the city of Deraa remains the only truly significant population center in relatively moderate rebel hands. As always in Syria, however, the reality may be rather more messy. Some experts doubt that Assad's government has sufficient forces -- even with Iranian-backed support that includes Hezbollah fighters and Afghan mercenaries -- to take or, more importantly, hold down the city and still have the energy to fight in the rest of the country.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-syria-aleppo-commentary-idUSKCN0XW25N
According to Jane's Information Group, a possible offensive on Homs by both al-Nusra Front and IS working independently might force the government to move critical forces away from Aleppo to defend key supply routes. After additional opposition gains during the 2015 Jisr al-Shughur offensive, Jane's said it was no longer possible for the SAA to properly reinforce Aleppo, leaving their forces vulnerable to any opposition or IS offensive on the city. If opposition forces decided to capitalize on their gains and launch an assault towards Latakia, the prospect of soldiers deserting was raised because if they were not redeployed back to defend it, they could defend their own homes against any potential rebel advance. Syrian government minister Faisal Mekdad stated in June 2015, "All our strategic planning now is to keep the way open to Aleppo to allow our forces to defend it".
=========

Hard to figure out what exactly is going on north of Aleppo. ISIS has advanced against some rebel militias, including FSA-affiliated ones. Here's the most comprehensible thing I can find on the overall situation: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-aleppo-idUSKCN0YI12E The upshot of the whole thing: "Aleppo's northern countryside is the theater of several separate battles between multiple warring sides in the five-year-old conflict, which has drawn in regional and world powers that back different groups. Rebels supplied through Turkey have been fighting Islamic State and separately battling Kurdish forces in other areas. " Clear as mud, with the whole thing appearing to be a kind of free-for-all.

 But there's this, too: http://syriadirect.org/news/new-north-aleppo-route-ends-fuel-crisis-bypasses-azaz-rebels/ Assuming this is true, and I do, it looks like ISIS and the Kurds are cooperating in keeping refined fuel flowing to other rebel militias farther south in the area of Idlib. This makes sense, because there's an economic reason to keep this trade going, no matter what the actual political/religious orientation of the various players, or how they might face off or align in the future. And rebel militias in Idlib are actually fighting the regime. The rebels enclaves in Azaz and Marea do not abut regime-held territory. Here's a map: http://syria.liveuamap.com/ So all of this put together, combined with the regime offensive in the south a couple of weeks ago, makes it seem to me that we're seeing the last gasp (perhaps a protracted last gasp) of the Sunni Arab rebel militias that existed from the beginning of the war. Pretty soon, we'll only have ISIS, the Kurds, and the regime. And right now, those three sides are divvying up whatever they can grab in anticipation of a reckoning some time in the next year or so. I don't think the main action by the regime will be in Aleppo this summer; I think it will be against Idlib, with the Kurds stepping in at the last moment to snatch up whatever they can before the Sunni rebels completely collapse. I should add that I may be utterly and completely wrong. Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and his allies in Moscow and Tehran have set the stage for an imminent offensive to complete the encirclement of Aleppo City following the near-total breakdown of Geneva peace talks and an associated ceasefire on April 19. Regime warplanes have resumed a campaign of aerial bombardment against opposition-held districts of Aleppo City. Meanwhile, pro-regime forces and their local partners have intensified their efforts to secure favorable terrain in advance of future operations in Aleppo Province. The current confluence of strategic intent, political opportunity, and tactical maneuvers indicate that the regime and its allies will act within the coming weeks to encircle and besiege Aleppo City.  Aleppo City-Syria’s largest urban center and commercial capital – constitutes the primary nexus of opposition strength in northern Syria. If successful, pro-regime forces could deliver a decisive blow to the powerful armed groups in Aleppo City that drives the opposition towards radicalization and a merger with Syrian Al-Qaeda affiliate Jabhat al-Nusra.

Most of the action in Syria since the partial encirclement of Aleppo three months ago has been in other places. But now it looks like Aleppo is once again the focus of the regime's efforts. I still don't think the regime will capture the city in the time frame given, but one interesting question is, assuming the regime takes control of the rebel-held areas of Aleppo, what about the Kurdish enclave in the northern part of the city? It's the red area of the map in this article: http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-36169006 Every map I've seen of Aleppo shows an area of Kurdish control, but I never thought anything about it until just now. Even if the regime were to take control of the city by July 1 (which I doubt it can), I don't think the regime would try to take on the Kurds immediately afterward. So even the elimination of rebel-held territory would mean that there was an area of Aleppo that the regime did not control. I think it's entirely possible that Assad and the Kurds might negotiate the handover of the Aleppo enclave for a concession elsewhere. The Kurds have been cooperating with the regime, including during the operation to cut off Aleppo in February, so a Kurdish-Assad deal for control of the city is not unthinkable. But in my opinion the presence of the Kurdish enclave in the city makes a "Yes" resolution of this question unlikely even if the regime retakes rest of the city by July 1, which as I say, I doubt they can do anyway. I'm leaving my forecast at 5% because nothing is completely impossible.

Even now (29/04/16) there is a 24-hour ceasefire in many different parts of Syria, including Damascus, but not in Aleppo. Even though these recent events seem to suggest an escalation of military action in and around Aleppo, it still seems very unlikely that the Syrian government will be able to retake Aleppo in only two months. Well articulated accounts by both @BG1 and others show that a military operation as complex as retaking the city will require overcoming difficult political and military obstacles.

One of the things I try to mentally adjust for when forecasting is something I call "News Distortion".    There's some sort of principle in physics that says that just by watching something, you change what occurs; "News Distortion", in my mind, is sort of the forecasting parallel. For example, on this question, once this question was launched I started paying particular attention whenever Aleppo appeared in the news.  It seems to me that Aleppo is in the news a lot lately.  Is that because I'm paying more careful attention?  Or is there really more going on in its vicinity?  Is my perception that there's increased activity DISTORTED by my increased attention??? Then there's questions like the Colombian government-FARC peace agreement, where there's not been much news in recent days.  When there's no news I tend to think "no news = no progress".  In this instance, the lack of news has distorted my perception in a negative way about what is occurring.   But that's not necessarily so, is it.  Maybe the lack of news is precisely because they ARE making progress, because they are closing in on a deal and are at a very fragile point in the negotiations, so have agreed to keep a news blackout.   Another example of what I call "News Distortion" is the way that the media can be sort of an echo chamber.  A car bomb explodes in Falluja, killing x people, and it is everywhere in the news, reported on from every angle, possibly with differing numbers of victims.  I find it really challenging to sort out the echoes and the updated reports from the original report.   Back to this question:  I am having a hard time discerning if we're really seeing the beginning of a Syrian government offensive against Aleppo, or if its just a mild escalation in hostilities, or even just what I call "News Distortion" because I'm paying more attention and the media's got echo turned up full volume.    That said, I've been reading for a while that it appears that the ceasefire is breaking down, so maybe I should increase my forecast.  I don't know if this is a harbinger of a big offensive to come, or not, so I'm thinking that my forecast increase shouldn't be extreme, especially since this question has a relatively near-term end date and requires not just the launching of an offensive, but the RETAKING of Aleppo.  I sure wish I had bought one of those crystal balls when they were on sale at Walmart!   Dang!  Since I didn't, I'll go with the crowd's forecast. . . .

Thursday, April 7, 2016
Aleppo Warning Update: April 7, 2016
By: Christopher Kozak Key Takeaway: Aleppo Province stands to become the focal point of a new round of violence in the Syrian Civil War even as the Geneva III Talks to end the conflict are scheduled to resume on April 13. Continued violations of an ongoing ‘cessation of hostilities’ by both pro-regime and opposition factions have fueled the largest outbreak of violence in northern Syria since the agreement went into effect on February 27, threatening to drive a wider breakdown of the tenuous ceasefire. Additional violence can also be expected in northern Aleppo Province over the coming weeks as Turkey and the U.S. vie over the course and composition of coalition-led efforts to sever the ground lines of communication between Ar-Raqqa City and the Syrian-Turkish Border. Turkey has worked to empower opposition groups in Aleppo Province in order to foil the territorial gains made by the Syrian Kurdish YPG, which the U.S. relies upon in the counter-ISIS fight. The regime and its allies also retain positions at the Kuweires Airbase from which to contest ISIS-held portions of Aleppo Province. This local competition for control over Aleppo Province – and the larger geopolitical struggle between the U.S., Russia, Iran, and Turkey that it reflects – will reach a critical boiling point in the coming months. 1. Hostilities Resume in Southern Aleppo Province: Syrian Al-Qaeda affiliate Jabhat al-Nusra and a coalition of other opposition groups – including several U.S.-backed Free Syrian Army (FSA)-affiliated factions – seized the strategic town of Al-Eis in southern Aleppo Province on April 1 following clashes that involved at least three SVBIED detonations. The Syrian Arab Army released a statement condemning the offensive as a major violation of the ‘cessation of hostilities’ and vowing to recapture the town, while opposition groups presented the attack as a justified counterattack in response to persistent ceasefire violations by pro-regime forces throughout the country. Pro-regime forces have mobilized for a counteroffensive amidst reports that Russia resumed its air campaign in Aleppo Province. Iran also announced the deployment of ‘advisors’ from its conventional armed forces in a significant inflection of its own intervention in Syria. The mounting military escalation in southern Aleppo Province heightened further on April 5 after prominent Salafi-Jihadist group Ahrar al-Sham downed a regime warplane over Al-Eis. The incident comes amidst persistent rumors that Turkey, Saudi Arabia, and other foreign actors may intend to provide the opposition with a small number of man-portable air defense systems (MANPADS) as a counter the air campaign being conducted by Russia in Syria. 2. Kurds and Opposition Skirmish in Aleppo City: The Syrian Democratic Forces – a coalition composed of the Syrian Kurdish YPG and allied opposition factions – clashed with Syrian Al-Qaeda affiliate Jabhat al-Nusra and other opposition groups in the Sheikh Maqsoud District of Aleppo City on April 5. Activist groups accused the Syrian Democratic Forces of cooperating with the regime in order to sever the key Castello Highway that supplies opposition-held Aleppo City. Long-standing tensions with the Syrian Kurds have flared into open violence in the past few months after the Syrian Democratic Forces assisted the regime in severing the primary ground line of communication between Aleppo City and Turkey in February 2016. 3. Turkish-Backed Opposition Advances on Syrian-Turkish Border: The Hawar Kilis Operations Room – a coalition of opposition groups backed by the U.S. and Turkey – seized the ISIS-held town of Al-Rai in northern Aleppo Province on April 7. Al-Rai serves as a key route for illegal cross-border smuggling of foreign fighters and supplies to ISIS in Syria. The advance comes as part of an ongoing offensive along the Syrian – Turkish Border that seized at least sixteen villages from ISIS since March 31. Turkey has intensified its provision of weapons, cross-border artillery fire, and other forms of support to opposition forces in northern Aleppo Province in recent months in a likely attempt to preclude further gains in the border region by the Syrian Kurdish YPG. 4. The U.S. and Turkey Spar Over Counter-ISIS Operations: The Syrian Democratic Forces – a coalition composed of the Syrian Kurdish YPG and allied opposition factions – announced preparations for an upcoming military operation to seize the ISIS-held city of Manbij in eastern Aleppo Province. Manbij is a major hub for foreign fighters and supplies transiting the Syrian-Turkish Border, thus representing a key objective for the U.S.-led coalition in its efforts to isolate Ar-Raqqa City. The operation nonetheless faces significant hurdles. Local Arab and Turkmen tribes have reportedly resisted overtures to participate in the operation due to the alleged mistreatment of civilians in regions previously-cleared by the Syrian Kurdish YPG. Meanwhile, Turkish President Recep Erdogan reportedly linked his support for the operation to demands for participating Sunni Arab factions to disavow their ties with the Syrian Democratic Forces as well as calls for the U.S. to provide additional air support to Turkish-backed opposition groups in northern Aleppo Province. The U.S. and Turkey held a technical meeting on April 4 in order to discuss the operation but the issue remains contentious given the links between the Syrian Kurdish YPG and the Kurdistan Workers’ Party (PKK), a designated terrorist group currently waging an active insurgency in southern Turkey.

Will the Syrian government forces retake the city of Aleppo before July 1, 2016? I think there is a 27% chance of this happening, because: The Syrian Army has the backing of Hezbollah, Iraqi Shiite militias, and the Iranian Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, which give needed manpower to a military quite depleted after almost five years of civil war. The number of fighters contributed by these groups is quite small, but demonstrates the willingness of foreign powers to support the Assad regime. If more success by the Syrian government seems likely, they may be willing to give greater assistance to Assad. However, that assistance is a small contributing factor to retaking Aleppo. +2% Russian military intervention is the linchpin for the Syrian Army's success so far in advancing on Aleppo. That support is not disappearing, despite media reports: http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/03/30/putins-attack-helicopters-and-mercenaries-are-winning-the-war-for-assad/ +15% The US and NATO allies do not plan to change their course of action in Syria. This makes the likelihood of moderate rebel groups receiving enough support to reverse their recent misfortune extremely unlikely. +5% Kurdish fighters are neutral to the Assad regime and have the support of the US because they are the most effective fighters against ISIS/Daesh. Given the likelihood they will secure routes north of Aleppo and cut off supplies to moderate rebels in the city, chances of continued assistance through these routes to rebels is slim. Because the Kurds are backed by the US, they are relatively free from Turkish ire, their main opponents in the region after ISIS/Daesh. With continued Kurdish success almost guaranteed and their neutral alignment with the regime, the position of rebels in Aleppo only grows more precarious. +5% However, sieges tend to be long, and the siege of Aleppo has not even truly begun yet. The regime has not yet encircled the city or cut off all supply lines to it. Given the length of most sieges is much longer than 3 months, it is strongly unlikely Syrian government forces will retake Aleppo before July 1, 2016. Also, recent ceasefire success suggests the Syrian Army will use a halt in violence around Aleppo to strengthen its position elsewhere. Because the ceasefire frees up the regime to commit troops to other fronts, the Syrian Army has an interest in prolonging the ceasefire until the advantages of attacking Aleppo outweigh the disadvantages. Because of the dwindling chance of resupplying Aleppo, a ceasefire also turns the battle into a war of attrition that the rebels will lose eventually. Finally, Assad rejects opposition demands, decreasing the likelihood of rebels disarming peacefully before July 1: http://www.cbsnews.com/news/syria-bashar-assad-rejects-transitional-body-opposition-geneva-peace-talks/ Without a full siege underway and a low chance of a diplomatic resolution to end the fighting completely, the chance of Syrian government forces to retake the city of Aleppo is unlikely: 27% ***** UPDATE: Upped to 35% due to news: http://www.syriadeeply.org/articles/2016/04/10312/syria-deeply-executive-summary-april-11/

Question is a bit fuzzy as far as what retake would really look like. 
Continued Russian air support could be vital to any operation and this will be maintained despite the "withdrawal" (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35812371) which increases the chances of success. 
Progress towards cutting off supply routes improves the chances of the regime to succeed with siege tactics which is what they are already exploring (http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/02/syria-aleppo-assad-russia/462231/). 
However, Aleppo is a rebel strong hold with several thousand opposition troops. The loss of the city would go a long way towards ending that dimension of the war in Syria (other than the fact that it might allow the government to redirect troops to the western part of the country the direct impact on ISIS will be limited) and as such it will not be given up easily. Allowing government forces to control all major urban centres in Syria legitimizes their role and strengthens their hand internationally as they would then be allied against ISIS with the wider international community. Any battle for complete control of Aleppo will be messy and likely prolonged.

I think there are two major factors at play here. First, there are tens of thousands of battle-hardened rebels in Aleppo. Second, there is a ceasefire currently in place that would ostensibly prevent the Assad regime from moving against Aleppo. If Assad wants to move against Aleppo with enough force to take the city, the ceasefire is over, which would reopen the war.  So, I think Assad will try to close in on Aleppo in small steps to try to strengthen his position, but I do not think he will try a full-on assault except as a last resort. I believe he would much rather pressure and divide the rebels and encourage defections and weaken their resolve. Assad may be in a strong position now, but we must keep his current force strength in perspective- his army is battered and weakened after 5 years of civil war, and even with Russian, Iranian and Hezbollah backup, the costs the rebels in Aleppo could impose on Assad's forces could easily make the battle prohibitive for Assad. I'm not sure about this. First, there's the matter of whether the ceasefire will be extended, and how many times. I think it's possible that in two weeks, it will be extended for another two weeks, then two after that, etc. I think the regime would be willing to go for this, for reasons I explain below. One problem the regime has in undertaking continuing operations in Aleppo is the vulnerability of the "dog leg" road linking the bulk of regime-held territory with Aleppo. This road has been cut twice in the past six months (although it was reopened by the regime), and ISIS holds the high ground overlooking the town of Khanaser, which is one of the few towns on the route. This vulnerability makes continued offensive action in Aleppo itself more difficult. In the most recent offensive to cut off Aleppo, some regime forces appear to have struck from Kurdish-held territory, but a direct land link between regime areas and Kurdish areas is even more tenuous than the dog leg road through the eastern steppe/desert. So another major effort in Aleppo may not be practical. I think over the next few months what the regime will focus on one of two things: shrinking al-Nusra's territory in Idlib province, or moving against ISIS to expand the area to secure its existing route to Aleppo.  Al-Nusra is fair game even under the ceasefire, and the next logical step after the relief of Idlib city is a push on to Aleppo to open a direct route from Latakia to Aleppo and effectively unite all regime-held territory into a solid bloc in the west. ISIS is also fair game, but driving ISIS troops from the hills around Khanaser will probably be as costly as an offensive in Idlib, and less strategically valuable overall. So my guess is that an offensive to open the route to Idlib is more likely than another major effort in Aleppo. So for the moment, the regime has an interest in the extension of the ceasefire because it offers an opportunity to shift resources to attacks on al-Nusra and ISIS, both of whom can be attacked without violating the ceasefire. If the regime does undertake the type of operation I'm guessing it will, and succeeds in relieving Idlib city and defeating al-Nusra, the regime will almost certainly wind up in control of Aleppo. But I'm not sure it will be in control there by July 1.
